results.title: Remorques = Stormy Waters
results.brief_description:
The captain of a tugboat is happily married but, when he rescues a boat from stormy waters, he falls in love with the wife of its captain. He leaves her to keep a vigil at the bedside of his own wife who is mortally ill. An intimate and perceptive study of passion and the nature of fidelity which benefits from a Prevert script and a trio of France’s top stars. Filmed partly on location in Brest, work began in 1939, was hampered by the restrictions imposed by the Nazis and was completed 2 years later in a Paris studio.

Credits: Producer, Roland Tual ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writer, Jacques Prevert ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Roland Manuel ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; assistant director, Louis Daquin.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Michele Morgan, Madeleine Renaud, Fernand Ledoux, Jean Marchat, Nane Germon, Charles Blavette, Alain Cuny.

results.title: Adieu Philippine
results.creator_credit: Jacques Rozier, Alain Raygot and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
In his last few months before military service, a young TV technician, on holiday, is torn bewteen two girls. Rozier’s first feature, using improvisation, amateur performers, hidden microphones and cameras in real locations, had a rough spontaneity very much in line with the aesthetics of the ‘nouvelle vague’. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Alain Raygot, Jean-Pierre Vic ; director, Jaqcues Rozier ; writers, Jacques Rozier, Michele O’Glor ; photography, Rene Mathelin ; music, Maxime Saury, Paul Mattei, Jacques Danjean.
Cast: Jean-Claude Aimini, Yveline Cery, Arlette Gilbert, Jeanne Perez, Chouquette Deschamps, Maurice Garrel, Vittorio Caprioli.

results.title: Journal D'une Femme de Chambre = Diary of a Chambermaid (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Michel Safra and Serge Silberman
results.brief_description:
Celestine takes up a position as chambermaid in a middle-class family and becomes the catalyst that reveals their sexual, religious and social repressions. The film, foot fetishism and all, is pure Bunuel, a sharp social satire in which the sexy, cruel and cool Jeanne Moreau is wonderful. Jean Renoir directed a version of ‘Le journal d’une femme de chambre’ in 1934.

Credits: Producers, Serge Silberman, Michel Safra; director, Luis Bunuel ; writers, Luis Bunuel, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Roger Fellous ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Michel Piccoli, Francoise Lugagne, Georges Geret, Jean Geret, Daniel Ivernel, Gilberte Geniat, Muni, Dominique Sauvage, Jean-Claude Carriere, Jean Ozenne, Andree Tainsy.

results.title: Le Signe du Lion = the Sign of Leo
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Claude Chabrol and Jean Cotet
results.brief_description:
An impoverished 40 year old American composer lives on the Left Bank in Paris. Hearing that he has inherited a fortune, he borrows money to hold a party, only to learn that the money has gone to a cousin. The ensuing crisis leads him by subtle degrees into becoming a tramp, begging outside cafes.

Credits: Producers, Claude Chabrol, Jean Cotet ; director, Eric Rohmer ; writers, Eric Rohmer, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Louis Saguer.
Cast: Jess Hahn, Van Doude, Michele Girardon, Jean Le Poulain, Paul Bisciglia, Jill Olivier, Christian Alers, Paul Crauchet, Stephane Audran.

results.title: Les Revoltes de Lomanach = the Rebels of Lomanach
results.brief_description:
In Vendee (western France) in 1799, Barnaud invades the estate of Lomanach with a group of Republican soldiers. Before the Revolution Barnaud used to be the estate manager of Lomanach. Monique, daughter of the owner, attempts to seduce Barnaud in order to kill him and save the estate. ‘Les Revoltes de Lomanach’ was France’s first widescreen feature presentation. This version is presented in standard screen ratio 3:4.

Credits: Producer, Francois Chavanne ; director, Richard Pottier ; writer, Jacques Sigurd, Leo Joannon ; photography, Jean Leherissey ; music, Georges van Parys ; assistant director, Claude Sautet ; costumes, Rosine Delamare.
Cast: Amedeo Nazzari, Dany Robin, Michel Vitold, Carla Del Poggio, Jacques Castelot, Jean Debucourt, Robert Dalban.

results.title: Le Misanthrope (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Alceste, disgusted with the hypocrisy of the world, has declared that there is no good in man and has vowed never to lie about the virtues of others. He is, of course, the misanthrope of the title. This attitude gets him into a considerable amount of trouble, including a law suit which he loses because he refuses to flatter the judge. Alceste is in love with the flirtatious and shallow Cime. So much so that is is incaplable of noticing in her the defaults he so despises in other people.

Credits: Director, Jacques-Gerard Cornu ; photography, Jean-Jacques Graude ; art direction, Willy Holt.
Cast: Jacques Dumesnil, Anouk Ferjac, Giselle Touret, Bernard Dheran, Jacques Charon.

results.title: Nathalie Granger
results.brief_description:
With little or no embellishment, film-maker Marguerite Duras offers a simple, often wordless chronicle of a woman’s day. She and her friend are seen doing yard work, talking about their families and receiving the occasional visitor. The brightest spot in the day is when a washing machine salesman comes to call.

Credits: Producer, Luc Moullet ; director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Marguerite Duras ; editor, Nicole Lubtchansky ; other crew, Benoit Jacquot, Bruno Nuytten, Michel Vionnet.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Lucia Bose, Gerard Depardieu, Valerie Mascolo, Dionys Mascolo, Luce Garcia-Ville.

results.title: L'horloger de Saint Paul = the Clockmaker of Saint Paul
results.brief_description:
For his first feature film, Bertrand Tavernier chose to transport the Simenon characters to his native town of Lyons. Michel Descombes works as a clockmaker in the St-Paul area of Lyons. One evening he finds the Police at his door asking about his son, Bernard. Bernard is suspected of shooting a security guard at a factory and has run away with his girlfriend. As the Police enquiry progresses, Michel realises he knows very little about his son and can hardly assist Commissioner Guiboud. The choice of Aurenche and Bost as screenwriters can be regarded as an anti ‘Nouvelle Vague’ statement from Tavernier. Both writers were strongly associated with film-makers such as Claude Autant-Lara and a more traditional style of cinema. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1973 ; Berlin Film Festival 1974 - Special Jury Prize.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Jean Aurenche, Pierre Bost, Bertrand Tavernier ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Jean Rochefort, Jacques Denis, Clotilde Joanno, Sylvain Rougerie, Christine Pascal, Monique Chaumette, William Sabatier.

results.title: Diabolo Menthe = Peppermint Soda
results.brief_description:
Kurys’ autobiographical first feature is an account of a year in the lives of two sisters - 13-year-old, introverted Anne, and outgoing 15-year-old Frederique - in the early 1960s. Avoiding sentimentality and nostalgia, the film charts the oppressions of a dreary, authoritarian school and the girls’ difficult relationships with their parents (a separated Jewish couple), their friends and each other. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1977. Also available on VHS in the National Collection.

Credits: Producer, Serge Laski ; director, writer, Diane Kurys ; photography, Philippe Rousselot ; music, Yves Simon.
Cast: Eleonore Klarwein, Odile Michel, Anouk Ferjak, Michel Puterflam, Yves Renier.

results.title: Chronopolis
results.brief_description:
Chronopolis is a city lost in space. The inhabitants are immortal and they attempt to relieve their boredom by manufacturing time. They are all awaiting a liberating cataclysm which will break the monotony of their endless lives. During one of their manufactured moments, the Chronossians meet a human being in the person of a mountaineer.

Credits: Producer, Marcelle Ponti ; director, Piotr Kamler ; writer, Piotr Kamler, Gabrielle Althen ; photography, Piotr Kamler ; music, Luc Ferrari.
Cast: Michel Lonsdale [narration].
